title: 104_hr4111
content: The Act titled "Federal Law Enforcement Dependents Assistance Act of 1996" provides educational assistance to dependents of slain federal law enforcement officers. It amends the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 to include educational benefits for dependents of civilian federal law enforcement officers killed or disabled in the line of duty. The subpart aims to enhance the appeal of service in civilian Federal law enforcement agencies, provide educational benefits to qualified dependents of officers who may not afford it due to death or disability, and help family members achieve the educational status they would have if not for the loss or disability of a parent or spouse. SEC. 1212 outlines the eligibility criteria and benefits for dependents of eligible Federal law enforcement officers, including financial assistance for education programs. The duration of benefits is limited to forty-five months of full-time education, with an age limit of 27 for dependent children. The Attorney General requires an application for assistance under this subpart, which will be approved unless the dependent is ineligible, their chosen educational institution does not meet requirements, their program does not meet criteria, or they are already qualified. The Attorney General will notify the dependent of approval or disapproval. The Attorney General requires an application for assistance under this subpart, which will be approved unless the dependent is ineligible, their chosen educational institution does not meet requirements, their program does not meet criteria, or they are already qualified. The Attorney General will notify the dependent of approval or disapproval in writing. The Attorney General can create regulations for this subpart. Assistance may be discontinued if the recipient fails to maintain satisfactory progress. The Attorney General may provide retroactive and prospective assistance to dependents of Federal law enforcement officers killed in the line of duty on or after May 1, 1992, for education at eligible institutions. Dependents can waive retroactive assistance and apply for prospective assistance instead. Definitions are provided in Section 1217. The term 'Attorney General' refers to the US Attorney General. 'Federal law enforcement officer' has the same meaning as in subpart 1. 'Program of education' includes coursework necessary for a specific educational or vocational goal. 'Eligible educational institution' is defined as an institution described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible for program participation. Eligible individuals can participate in programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the implementation of programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965.
